title: Holme Styes Reservoir Walking Route

images.title: John Fielding / Holme Styes Reservoir
images.caption: Holme Styes Reservoir. Looking to the dam head.

images.title: John Fielding / Holme Styes Reservoir Dam Head & Outflow
images.caption: Lovely countryside surrounding the lake.

images.title: Alexander P Kapp / Holmes Styes Reservoir
images.caption: Looking NW from Long Ing Road towards the reservoir.

images.title: John Fielding / A Boundary Wall alongside Fox Clough
images.caption: A Boundary Wall alongside Fox Clough to the west of the reservoir.

images.title: Stephen Craven / Footpath across the River Ribble at Holme Styes
images.caption: Footpath across the River Ribble at Holme Styes. The lesser-known River Ribble, that is, the Yorkshire one (a minor tributary of the Holme) rather than the Lancashire one. The footpath from Greave Road descends the steep field on the east side of the river, crosses it by a footbridge and turns left to ascend more gently into the woods on the west bank. The body of water on the left is the settling pond of the redundant treatment works (now demolished)

images.title: Stephen Craven / Old water treatment works
images.caption: Old water treatment works. The treatment works at Holme Styes reservoir was abandoned in 1995. This photo shows the old sludge settling tanks being pumped out before being filled in and the site restored to grassland. The main building was retained as a pumping station.

description: This walk visits the pretty Holme Styes Reservoir near Holmfirth in Yorkshire. It's a lovely quiet spot and something of a hidden gem of the area. You can find the small lake just over 2 miles south of Holmfirth. On the eastern side of the water there's some roadside parking where you can start the walk. From here you can pick up a circular trail running around the reservoir, part of which uses the Kirklees Way .  You could head west along this waymarked footpath to explore the woodland to the west of the site.
